body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Command line run `adb`

### Expected behavior

```console
Android Debug Bridge version 1.0.41
Version 33.0.0-8141338
Installed as D:\Android\SDK\platform-tools\adb.exe

global options:
 -a                       listen on all network interfaces, not just localhost
...
```


### Actual behavior

```console
adb: The term 'adb' is not recognized as a name of a cmdlet, function, script file, or executable program.
Check the spelling of the name, or if a path was included, verify that the path is correct and try again.
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.3.0-preview.2
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.3.0-preview.2
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.22000
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```


### Visuals

Right click inside a folder and open a terminal, type `adb`, enter and run, it will report an error.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42903751/157232885-76c11fcd-7a26-46e6-be83-63100b460855.png)

But right click on the Microsoft icon, open windows terminal, and type `adb` to run it normally.
adb is already configured in the system environment variable;
My computer system is Win11 Professional, I have this problem with the default Powershell, and I still have this problem with the latest version of github terminal;
I don't know why this is happening?

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42903751/157232974-e5ab2f8f-cec4-45e2-9ba2-07bcccd6522d.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42903751/157233025-b779a9f3-ed17-4dc1-bad4-4c125decdaa8.png)

comments.author: 237dmitry
comments.body:
Is `adb` in the `$env:Path`? If not you should run it with a relative or full path even if it is in the current directory:
```
PS > .\adb
```

comments.author: xmhwws
rkeithhill
comments.body:
> The picture below shows me right-clicking on a folder to open windows terminal

When you launch Windows Terminal from another app, it inherits the environment (including the PATH) from that app.  What is the app where you are right-clicking on a folder - File Explorer or ?  I suspect a reboot would eliminate this issue.

comments.author: xmhwws
iSazonov
comments.body:
> But it's strange, isn't it true that the environment variables in windows take effect in time?

There is an issue for this in Windows Terminal repository.

comments.author: rkeithhill
comments.body:
> isn't it true that the environment variables in windows take effect in time

It depends on the app that PowerShell is launched from since PowerShell inherits that environment.  Some apps can listen for system/user environment variable changes and update their environment accordingly.  I thought that File Explorer was an app that did that but perhaps not.  Or given that you're on Windows 11, maybe this is **another** thing they fubar'd in Windows 11.  Either way, this is not an issue with PowerShell.
